description.narrative: 1. Number of statistical areas assessed towards compliance with international/EU standards in statistics policy-makers’ needs. 2. Number of methodologies and toolkits (incl. administrative data sources) developed/ revised from the perspective on international/EU requirements in statistics 3. Number of tools focused and actions on “quality of statistical output” developed to comply with European norms and best practices and to build necessary national capacities 4. Number of statistical surveys designed (complying with international/EU requirements) and carried out to respond to policy-making information needs 5. Number of stat.staff whose capacities to collect produce quality disaggregated data within statistical sample surveys are built, by topics explored, to make more data available for the research and policy development 6. Number of professional development events carried out and/or training materials (curriculum, manuals, guides) for stat.staff implemented 7. Number of user-friendly statistical outputs developed disseminated, no of areas covered 8. Level of data users’ satisfaction with statistical outputs periodically measured and feedback provided 9. Number of data user capacity building initiatives carried out/institutionalized, topics covered, trainees from Gov., CSOs, media whose statistical literacy strengthened 10. Number of policy documents being assisted with ME tools (stat.indicators, guidance) to contribute to their efficiency and effectiveness 11. Number of research/analytical papers to analyze less explored topics developed on the basis of available statistics in participatory manner

comment.narrative: 1. Statistical areas are not assessed on compliance with EU requirements/standards 2. Moldovan statistical system still suffers from inconsistent methodologies, multiplicity of data sources, fragmented statistical activities in line ministries 3. Data production systems are not fully covered by the international standards related to quaility of statistical outputs and processes 4. Insufficient number and varity of statistical surveys to cover all the information needs 5. Inadequate resources and lack of continuous training and capacity building for statisticians 6. There are limited opportunities for professional development of data producers to comply with actual requirements and international standards in the field 7. Data dissemination covers only core statistical areas and is done through traditional means of communication; 8. Most of indicators are not disaggregated by sex, age, and geographical territory; and even existing disaggregated indicators are often not disseminated and are not easily accessible which do not meet users' needs and satisfaction. 9. Data users have insufficient skills and capacities to efficiently use statistics for participatory policy-making 10. Government’s monitoring evaluation capacities are weak 11. Data/evidence-based analysis is poorly applied to analyze the current situation, develop policies, monitor their implementation and evaluate impact, as well as to assess to what extent Moldova is fulfilling its obligations under economic, social and cultural rights.

1. Comparative analysis of at least 2 statistical surveys undertaken to assess their compliance with EU/international standards and feasibility to measure women’s entrepreneurship 2. Feasibility analysis of Harmonized Set of Gender Sensitive Development Indicators in the context of Government’s reporting on implementation of National Program on Ensuring Gender Equality and its action plan undertaken; data gaps/difficulties/weaknesses in definitions, sources, processing instruments, quality aspects described to be taken into consideration for drafting of a new National Action Plan 4. Results of gender-sensitive statistical surveys disseminated in at least one user-friendly statistical publication (‘Women Men’), and one e-application responding to data users’ needs 8. Not applicable in 2014 9. National strategy on development of statistical system developed; Recommendations on improvement of Government’s ME activity developed to tackle gender equality and women’s entrepreneurship 11.1. description.narrative: Elections - elections

1. Centre for Continuous Electoral Training has improved capacities and training curricula, methodologies and materials, as well as a pool of certified electoral trainers (at least 40) available 2. Electoral reforms supported through provision of expertise and facilitation of dialog and consultations with Civil Society Organisations and general public on the reform actions 3. Political parties finance transparency improved through expertise and training for the implementation of the law on political party financing 4. Central Electoral Commission has a modern population register with an addresses system and inter-operable with other key state registers

comment.narrative: 1. Centre for Continuous Electoral Training lacks basic capacity to organize and conduct electoral training as this is a new institution: lack of training modules, materials, curricula; lack of a pool of professional trainers 2. Electoral reform needed in the areas of electoral administration; electoral systems; voter registration, as indicated in several OSCE/ODIHR reports 3. Law on political party financing absent 4. The State and Central Electoral Commission lacks a modern population register with an address system, integrated with other key state registers

1. Center for Continuous Electoral Training provides training to 20,000 electoral administrators ahead of the local elections 2. Population registration system concept developed 3. Political parties financing reform implementation supported through expertise and training for parties and Central Electoral Commission on monitoring of financing. 4. At least 2 e-registers relevant for the Voters’ Register developed and inter-operable

1. Center for Continuous Electoral Training (CCET) provided training to 11225 electoral administrators ahead of the General Local Elections 2015. Capacities of Gagauz lower level EMB strengthened though trainings delivered by CCET. 2. Preparations for development of population registration concept and support to Civil Status Service (CSS) - ongoing. Strategy for the institutional modernization of the CSS and optimization of business processes – ongoing. 3. Political parties financing reform implementation supported through international expertise. The Central Electoral Commission and political parties’ capacities strengthened during a BRIDGE workshop on Political Financing. 4. Address system draft law finalized after a large consultations with stakeholders. Amendments to other legal acts related to adoption of Address System Law prepared. Technical specifications of Address Register IT system drafted. 5. Technical specifications for other registers drafted (Ministry of Defense) 6. Semantic interoperability in the process of development. Interoperability legal and regulatory framework drafted.

Further MEBP II promotion and awareness raising meetings will be held at district/region/city level in 3 areas (I (South), II (North), III (Center) and Transnistria with the participation of around 600 people. 5. 90 representative meetings on project promotion and community mobilization will be organized with the participation of around 2000 community members. 6. 90 assessments will be carried out to identify local needs and capacities to implement biomass projects. 7. 45 participatory evaluations of project proposals will be organized with the involvement of local public authorities, community stakeholders and other community members in decision making process.

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

* Number of municipal leaders trained. * Number of fuel suppliers trained. * Number of children participating in awareness activities. * Number of specialized Vocational Education Training Programmes on Renewable Energy Sources and Energy Efficiency

comment.narrative: Training and education materials and approaches developed and applied during first MEBP phase

1. 17 community leaders from 17 communities from the South region of the country (incl. UTAG) equipped with basic technical, operational and managerial knowledge and skills required for ensuring the sound administration and operation of biomass heating systems installed in public institutions 2. 50 operating biofuel producers with enhanced knowledge and new skills in the field of biomass quality management and solid biomass standards. 21 potential fuel suppliers increased their knowledge and capacities in the area of biomass fuel production. 3. EU Sustainable Week event organized with participants of the Summer Camp “Energel” 2015 edition who organized a Flash mob for raising awareness on renewable energy and energy efficiency. Green-energy festival “Sun Da-I Fest”, National Youth week in Moldova, UN Days in Moldova organized and contributed to the successful implementation of the awareness raising activities. “Green Energy” network added 25 young members. 4. Educational activities on renewable energy use and benefits, including school lessons within the “Renewable Energy Sources”, thematic webinars, discussions clubs, public presentations in communities and to parents-organized in 18 schools from the first beneficiary communities of MEBP second phase and engaged over 1,180 children during 2015 school year. 18 teachers and school principals trained in the area of renewable energy use, didactical methods and techniques provided with “Teachers’ Guide” pertaining to “Renewable Energy Sources” optional course and the students were equipped with the Manual for Children. 5. Bioenergy Camp “Energel” organized and knowledge delivered to 70 most active promoters of renewable energy and wise energy consumption through workshops and practical experiments using wind energy,eco-homes,eco-shows. 6. by the end of 2015, over 1,046 local leaders, including 804 women (or 72%), managed due to their ability to collect funds and create local partners to efficiently collect 944,275.40

1. 1324 community leaders (including 1002 women and 322 men) managers of public institutions from beneficiary communities enhanced their knowledge in mobilization of local resources, management of biomass heating systems and sustainability and participative ME of biomass heating projects. Another 80 mayors, school and kindergarten directors acquired necessary skills pertaining to sustainable procurement of solid biomass. 2. Up to 79 fuel suppliers participated in 6 regional training courses on the subject "Pellet and briquette production"and "Business management in the field of pellets and briquettes production" 3.More than 3100 pupils participated in the MEBP "Educational Innitiative" that includes: Spring School on RES in Transnistria, Summer School "Energel", optional course on RES for students from 7th - 9th grades taught in more than 100 schools, partnership with Moldova Ecological Movement, on-line webinars. 4. Educational Initiative on Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency for the school year 2015-2016 successfully completed. new activities have been set up with the Ministry of Education, for continuing educational initiatives in the next year. 5. Bioenergy Summer Camp “Energel” for best students engaged in the Educational Initiative successfully conducted. 6. Two educational programmes pertaining to renewable enrgy sources have been approved for piloting in three VET schools. The module on "Energy Plants" is piloted within VET Schools from Cuhurestii de Sus and Orhei while the module on "Operators in the biomass boiler room" is piloted within VET School Nr.3 from Chisinau. The curriculum for both occupations have been approved by the Ministry of Education 7. 1002 women and 322 men have been trained in subjects related to solid biomass during 2016.

comment.narrative: 1. 300+ Media materials (reports and TV programmes, radio news, newspaper articles, news for web portals and news agencies) broadcasted/disseminated, highlighting the opportunities and benefits of bioenergy for Moldova, project results/activities, success stories of people heating their houses with biomass energy, success stories of schools and kindergartens that moved from gas and coal-based heating to biomass-based heating, and businesses launched in biofuel production; women success stories. 2.10 public events organized in various formats showcasing the project objectives and results achieved and promoting the green technologies among the people. 3.20 press releases developed and widely disseminated to national and regional media institutions and project partners. 4.6 editions of project electronic newsletters, issued every two months-developed in Romanian, Russian, and English languages and distributed to project partners, media institutions, promoted on social media networks, project and partners web pages. 5. 300+ persons informed about renewables 6.Participants at Moldova Eco-Energetica Award Ceremony acknowledged the significance of the event nation wide.

1. Over 400 media materials (TV, Radio, newspapers, web portals) were published about the benefits of green energy, and impact of project results for green economy start-up in Moldova; 2. 12 public events organised to present the project activities and results 3. 18 press releases about project initiatives results were disseminated to media project partners/beneficiaris, and were placed on the www.biomasa.md and Project Facebook account Energie din Biomasă. 4. 6 editions of project newsletter were developed in RO, RU EN languages and disseminated to media, project partners, beneficiaries, and promoted on social media networks, project web page 5. Over 350 persons requested from the project team via email, telephone, letters, visits to the project office information about project activities and next interventions 6. Participants to the Moldova Eco Energetica Award ceremony valued with high and very high appreciations (90%)

description.narrative: 1. An integrated e-system for the collection of criminal justice data developed and put in use within the Prosecution Service. 2. Number of prison facilities` staff members covering 100% of prison facilities from Moldova trained on torture prevention and combating standards as per UN Committee against Torture 2010 recommendations. 3.1.Proportion of staff members from Goian Prison for Juveniles trained in application of anger management/violence reduction techniques in the daily interaction with inmates. 3.2. Vocational training workshop established at Goian Prison for Juveniles and equipped with basic instruments and tools to carry out vocational training activities. 4. Quality assurance mechanisms developed in line with ISO 17025 requirements put in place at the National Center for Judicial Expertise; number of staff trained on implementation of ISO 17025 requirements. 5. Proper space and facilities for practice oriented exercises created and put in use by the National Institute of Justice by the end of intervention.

comment.narrative: 1. Divergent criminal justice statistics due to inefficient data collection mechanism. 2. UN Committee against Torture 2010 recommendations on training of the detention facilities` staff members to prevent and combat torture and other forms of ill-treatment not yet fully implemented. 3.1.Low skills and capacities of personnel from Goian Prison for Juveniles to take over educational/correctional tasks according to the principle of dynamic security: 10% of the staff is well-trained; 50% of the existing personnel have participated in at least one training. 3.2. No conditions for vocational training of inmates at Goian Prison for Juveniles. 4. National Center for Judicial Expertise lacks a quality assurance mechanism, developed in line with ISO 17025 requirements; the staff has limited understanding and capacities to implement the ISO 17025 standard. 5. Technical capacities of the National Institute of Justice to deliver practice oriented initial training are limited: one training room poorly equipped and unsuitable for professional training purpose.

description.narrative: The project will support Moldova with the National Adaptation Planning process which fosters the system and capacities for medium-to long term adaptation planning and budgeting.

The goal of the project is to ensure that Moldova has a system and capacities in place for medium- to long term adaptation planning and budgeting, with the aim to reduce vulnerability of population and key sectors to the impacts of climate change.
independent political entity

At the same time, as a result of capacity building activities involving international expertise, the Equality Council has increased capacities on using legal technics, analysis, argumentation in drafting decisions and generally improved decisions drafting skills. 4. 1. More than 10 cross-river business exchanges and partnerships received supported in 2016, including, inter alia, a Memorandum of cooperation and a joint work plan for 2016 signed between two agricultural business associations from both banks– Moldova Fruct and Dnestrovskii Frukt, the consolidation of a business platform supporting collaboration between more than 30 young entrepreneurs on both banks, business forums, etc. 2.1 At least 60 enterprises from both banks (28 from TN) benefited from business support services in 2016, including 31 newly created enterprises via the Grants for Youth Programme (16 from the Transnistrian region, 18 led by women), 5 companies from both banks (including 2 from Transnistrian region) supported to promote their exports, 24 fruit producing companies from both banks (10 from the left bank) representing two agricultural business associations (Moldova Fruct and Dnestrovskii Frukt) benefiting from trainings 2.2 More than 150 jobs are on track of being created (more than 40% for women, 78 in the Transnistria region) by the 31 young entrepreneurs supported via the Grants for Youth Programme; 2.3 At least 2,000 women and men benefited from access to opportunities for improved livelihoods, including the employees of the companies supported through the projects, attendees of business plan training courses, etc. 2.4 Representatives of companies providing Business Development Services from both banks (more than 50% women) got acquainted with best practices in providing BDS as a result of 2 study visits (Poland, Cyprus). The Rezina Business Incubator established contacts with a counterpart from the Transnistrian region (Intereconomservice, Ribnitsa) to undertake future joint projects and an agreement has been established to organise cross-river discussions to better understand DCFTA requirements for export and address the challenges faced in the Transnistrian region through EBA (European Business Association) implication; Also, a needs assess

1. Achieved – draft NES 2017-2021 developed in a participatory manner and submitted for official approval 2. Achieved: Two workshops for the inter-ministerial technical working group and three bilateral meetings of the MLSPF on designing NES 2017-2021 organized 3. Achieved: Seven public consultations on the draft NES were organized - four in Chisinau and three in Cahul, Balti and Comrat with circa 188 local stakeholders from public institutions, civil society, business and employees associations, educational institutions, local employment agencies, local and regional public authorities; One press event organized on employment issues; Two workshops on synchronizing the draft National Employment Strategy and the draft employment Strategy organized. 4. Partially - Updated Terms of references and operations’ manual for the institutionalization of reintegration focal points accepted by NEA – to be enforced starting 2016; 5. Achieved: Report on TEAs capacity developed, capacity building programme for TEA reintegration focal points developed; 10 pilot TEAs selected based on specific methodology and approved by NEA 6. Achieved: Two training modules of 2,5 days each, 10 coaching sessions and two networking events on migration, communication, service improvement, team building, etc. delivered to 74 national and local reintegration focal points which have knowledge, skills and regulations/procedures in place to provide better services to returned migrants (including up to 19% men); One training, of two days delivered to 25 non-pilot reintegration focal points. 7.2500 migrants benefited from adjusted services of NEA 8. Achieved: Report reflecting migrants’ perspective and views on the services provided by NEA developed, using user-led and innovative research tools. 9. comment.narrative: 1.11% of the EU Directives and Regulations included in the Association Agreement are transposed in the national legislation. 2.An ineffective parliamentary oversight on the EU integration agenda. 3.Underdeveloped cooperation between Parliament and independent institutions (Ombudsman, Court of Accounts) 4.The cooperation between Parliament and CSOs, media and citizens is rather weak. 5.There are weak systems and processes for information management within the Parliament.

1. Baseline Assessment of Committees and needs of Secretariat staff performed. 2. Draft Parliamentary Action Plan for Association Agreement and DCFTA, tracking and reporting mechanism developed. 3. Roadmap and Plan of Activities for Committee on Human Rights developed. 4. A detailed roadmap for achieving parliamentary openness developed. At least 20 MPs and 30 parliamentary staff trained on Open Parliament principles and Open Data standards 5. A detailed roadmap on the implementation of E-Parliament developed.

1. Partially achieved. A service provider to perform the Baseline Assessment of Committees contracted. The task will be finalized by February, 2017. 2. The Parliamentary Action Plan for Association Agreement and DCFTA as well as the tracking and reporting mechanism were developed and presented to Parliament. 3. Roadmap and Plan of Activities for Committee on Human Rights developed and presented to Parliament. 4. Partially achieved. A Roadmap for achieving parliamentary openness was developed. 34 parliamentary staffers and 15 representatives of CSOs were trained on engaging through dialogue with civil society in parliamentary processes (legislative, oversight and budget). No MPs were trained. 5. Achieved. Future ICT Architecture Document of PRM (To Be Vision) was developed. A draft ICT Transformation Plan and the technical specifications for the development of the IT system e-Parliament developed.
